section.title: Document Information
section.para: This document provides an in-depth description of the Fusion Corporate Channels Release 6.0 front-end for users at a bank site, working in Bank Trade Services. The functions available cover the set of modules offered in the application to enable banks to review the transactional messages sent by their clients, export them in PDF format, reply to them or generate reporting messages based on existing transaction records.
New transactions can also be created such as the notification of Export Letters of Credit (Commercial and Standby) to beneficiaries or Import Documentary Collections to drawees.
The following modules are covered in this manual:

section.title: Audience
section.para: This manual is addressed to a user at a bank, and describes the end-user functions in the bank user interface.

section.title: Terminology
section.para: A Fusion Corporate Channels system is used by two types of organisation: banks, and companies that are customers of banks. The latter are referred to as "customers" or "clients" - these two terms are used interchangeably.
In addition, the term "bank group" is used to mean a site with overriding authority over the system, such as a bank's head office.
A member of the staff of a client or bank is called a "user". A user with special administrator privileges is called an "administrator".
A Fusion Corporate Channels system has two different user interfaces: for a user at a client, and for a user at a bank or bank group.

The client interface has a section called Services, and the bank interface has a section called System Features, containing functions for administering and configuring the Fusion Corporate Channels system. The rest of the interface contains end-user functions. Which functions are available to a given user depends on that user's privileges.

section.title: Products and Transactions
section.para: The financial products that a bank can provide, such as letters of credit, standby letters of credit, shipping guarantees, loans, and so on, are referred to as "products".

The communications between bank and client about an individual instance of a product typically consist of a sequences of messages. For example, the communications regarding a letter of credit would typically consist of:

listitem.para: The client's initial request
The bank's formal response
Possibly a request from the client to amend the request
The bank's formal response to the amendment request
Possibly a free-format message from the client to the bank containing further discussion
The bank's response to the free-format message
Possibly further free-format messages between the client and the bank

section.para: These individual messages are called "transactions" or "transaction events". Those sent by the bank in reply to a client message are called "reporting messages" (because the bank is "reporting back" - they should not be confused with reports produced using the Report Designer module). The whole set of messages concerning one instance of a individual product is called a "file" (this represents a "file of documents" and should not be confused with the files that can be uploaded containing details of a transaction).
The initial request from the client is often called the "initiation" of the file.

section.title: System ID
section.para: When a new file is created - for example, a client user creates a new Letter of Credit request - Fusion Corporate Channels gives it a unique reference number called its System ID. This is used throughout the system to identify it.
The System ID consists of a 2 charactered Product code describing the type of transaction, followed by the year and month and a unique number allocated to this transaction file.

section.title: Permissions
section.para: Which fuctions and facilities you, as a Bank user, have access to, and what you can do in each section, depends on permissions granted you by your Bank's Fusion Corporate Channels administrator.

Your permissions are often referred to as privileges, authority or authorisation. These four terms are used interchangeably, but should not be confused with authentication, which means your login ID and password.

section.title: Date and Amount Formats
section.para: When entering a date in a date field, two formats are available. You can enter it in the form DD/MM/YYYY or DDMMYY if your locale is for instance France, or in the form MM/DD/YYYY or MMDDYY if your locale is for instance the USA..

informalexample.para: For example, entering 180401 produces a display of 18/04/2001, which in a French locale corresponds to 18th April 2001.

section.para: When you enter an amount, the system automatically formats the value entered according to the currency selected. You can either enter the amount using the decimal and group delimiters of your locale (for example, respectively [,] and [space] for France, or [.] and [,] for Singapore), or directly as a series of digits.

informalexample.para: For example, 123456.00 in a Singaporean locale produces a display of 123,456.00 if the currency involved is associated with 2 decimal places.

section.title: Forward and Back Browser Buttons Behaviour
section.para: When you use a Browser's Forward and Back buttons, the browser's default behaviour is displayed and Fusion Corporate Channels doesn't provide any customised messages.

section.title: Antivirus Scanning Service
section.para: This service provides an interface from Fusion Corporate Channels to an antivirus scanner of your company's choice. You can scan any attachment for viruses before uploading it from any transaction screen in Fusion Corporate Channels.

note.para: This service is enabled by the Fusion Corporate Channels Administrator.

section.title: Common Features
section.para: Many options, when selected, display a page that lists relevant records. These list pages have some things in common:

listitem.para: You can enter search criteria in a group of fields at the top of the page and click Search , to make the list show only records that match these criteria. These fields represent the most important fields in the record, as do the columns in the table.
You can use wildcards in these fields. The wildcard character is an asterisk (*). You can use it anywhere in a field.

On pages where the list might be very long - for example, if there are many transactions - the list is not displayed until you have entered the search criteria and clicked Search. In these cases, enter an asterisk in any of the search fields to get the entire list.
If a company has entities defined in its profile, then a column and a search criterion field for Entity appear in addition to the columns and fields mentioned in the individual descriptions below.
You can click the triangular icons in the heading of a column to sort the display on that column in ascending or descending order.
There may be a column where you can click to open the individual record for viewing or editing. These are described in the sections for the individual options.

section.title: The Fusion Corporate Channels Bank Home Page
section.para: Once logged in, the Bank Home page will be displayed.
Each of the sections of the Fusion Corporate Channels Bank Home page are listed here:

listitem.para: The Fusion Corporate Channels Banner
The Tool bar
Recent Applications
Pending Counterparties Applications
Navigation lists

section.para: In many cases, there are multiple methods of navigating to specific functions or options. Some of these methods will be discussed in this guide.

section.title: The Banner
section.para: The Fusion Corporate Channels banner is the same on every page, with the Finastra or bank's logo on the left hand side.

To its right side are the following details available on the banner:
Bank Business Date and Timezone - This is available only when the property show.bank.datetime is set to 'true'. The user can set this property to true when the bank timezone and user timezone are different.
Last login details

The banner header is followed by the following three sections:
The user login name and bank name.
Manage profile link (followed by your login name and bank name) that allows the user profile, Password, and Security questions to be changed.
Languages Select Box- Allows the user to change the language of FCC.
Logout button to log out of the Fusion Corporate Channels.
As the banner is displayed on all pages, these options can be selected at any time.

section.title: The Tool bar
section.para: Below the banner on the Home page, is the Tool bar. The Tool bar is displayed on all pages of the Fusion Corporate Channels Client Portal.

The Tool bar provides the Home button
. Click on this button while displaying any page in the Fusion Corporate Channels to return the user to the Home page.

section.title: Welcome Message
section.para: Beneath the toolbar, is the Welome Message from the Bank.
This may change depending on the bank's definitions.

section.title: Recent Applications
section.para: In the center of the screen, below the Tool bar, is a list of transactions that have been completed by the client but not yet actioned by the bank. Click in the System ID of each one to process, approve or reject them.

These are grouped according to the entities assigned to the user's company, and provide an immediate summary of outstanding amounts for each transaction that has been entered into. Clicking on any of the list headings will allow the list to be sorted according to that column value.

section.title: Recent Counterparties Activation
section.para: Below the Recent Applications is a list of all pending activations for registered counterparties. The are additional parties associated with Client transactions. Click on each Counterparty ID to process them.

section.title: Navigation List
section.para: At the bottom on the left hand side of the page, is the navigation list.
This list shows the functions, features and facilities the user is authorised to use. Note that not all the items shown here will be available. This document describes Middle-Office functions only.

section.title: Change Profile Function
section.para: This module has just one function on the System Features menu, called Change Profile.
All users can use the Change Profile module to view and update their language and password. No particular jurisdiction is required to use this feature.
When you click this function, you are presented with a form to update your profile.

section.para: After entering your changes, click Save at the bottom of the form.
When the password is changed, the password expiry date is computed and stored, and the invalid login attempts counter is reset.
Depending on the system parameters, the new password may be checked against previously used passwords, and may be rejected. This prevents you simply re-using the same password.

chapter.title: Middle-Office
chapter.para: The features gathered under the term of Middle-Office are related to the actions taken by a bank playing an active role in a Trade Finance transaction.

All the products (Import and Export Letters of Credit, Shipping Guarantees, Financing Requests, Export and Import Documentary Collections, Banker's Guarantees, Issued and Received Standby LCs, Issued and Received Letters of Indemnity, Fund Transfers and Inward Remittances) available in the system can be manipulated using the Middle-Office module, using the functions on the menu that you access by clicking Middle-Office on the main menu on your home page.

note.para: The availability of the Middle-Office menu and its functions is dependent on the permissions assigned to the user. Only those functions the user is authorised to use will be displayed.

section.title: Categories of Action
section.para: In this module you can do the following:

varlistentry.term: Reply to an initiation submitted to the bank by one of its clients

listitem.para: An "initiation" is defined as any message sent by the client to the bank. For example, a request for issuance of a new Letter of Credit, an amendment of its terms, the creation of a new Guarantee, a new Financing Request, the delivery of new collection instructions by a drawer to the Remitting Bank, or any update sent using a free format message.

varlistentry.term: Create a new Reporting message on an existing transaction record

listitem.para: This communication is initiated by the bank handling a transaction and is used to notify the customer of a new event that has occurred on the transaction. For example, the Issuing Bank of a Letter of Credit could send an advice of discrepancies to the importer when the documents have been received from the negotiating bank, or alternatively trace its customer for the payment of a sight bill under an LC.

varlistentry.term: Create a completely new transaction record

listitem.para: This is used to notify the export customer of a new Export Letter of Credit (Commercial or Standby) or to notify a client of a new Import Collection for which that client is the designated drawee.

section.para: Each of these categories represents an option appearing as a menu item of the Middle-Office screen, which you reach from your home page.

In all cases, you can have several users validate the message before it is sent to the customer. To do this, the bank to sets up an authorisation matrix for its users to implement a four-eyes principle or a jurisdiction based on the amounts reported. This mechanism is the same as the one available on the customer side to provide several levels of control on the submission of transactions.

section.title: Pending Records
section.para: The pending records that you see are the transaction events that have been submitted to your bank by its clients. They are now waiting for an acknowledgement by the bank's Trade Services, which has to decide if the related requests can be approved and hence processed in the back-office operations of the bank.

Until a pending record has been approved by the bank through this option, the record is not seen by the client as Existing (if it is a creation of a transaction), Amended or Updated. In other words, its new or updated details have not been committed to the master of this transaction record as long as the acknowledgement has not been applied.

section.title: Pending Records - Process flow
section.para: The mechanism of generation of the reply and the associated work flow for the bank user is listed in the following:

listitem.para: You review the list of pending records, either from your home page or from the consolidated list.
You select a record by clicking on its Fusion Corporate Channels assigned reference number to see more details than the summary appearing in the list.
An input form is displayed with the following capabilities:

You can review the details of the event as well as the full details of the transaction itself. You can print or export these details as a PDF format. You can leave the form for now and return to it later, if some processing / validation is required in the back-office before you can create the acknowledgement message.

After reviewing the details, and after the back-office has processed the request, you can use the first part of the reporting form to enter the text details of the message that will be sent as an acknowledgement to the customer together with any attachments.

note.para: If you need to alter the details of the transaction record as a consequence of the processing by the back office (for instance if some modifications have been provided by the user by phone), it is advisable to convey these changes in a subsequent reporting message (sent from the Existing Records menu item). This will keep the consistency between the data of the back-office and the file that will be displayed to the customer as part of his reporting. And since it is an additional reporting message, the customer still has access, via the transaction history, to the original details as well as the updated details.

section.para: After selecting the Middle Office option from the Administrator's list on the home page, the Pending Records function can be selected from the left side navigation menu.

Click an entry in the list to rapidly open the reporting form and show its full details.

section.title: Existing Records
section.para: For various reasons throughout the life of an International Trade transaction, the bank handling the transaction (as the Issuing Bank of an LC, SI, LI, RI, SG, TF or FT transaction, the Recipient or Issuing Bank for a BG, the Advising Bank for an EL, SR, the Remitting Bank for an EC or IR or the Presenting Bank for an IC) may need to send various transactional messages to its customers.

A typical use of this feature is for the bank to notify an exporter about an amendment to a Export Letter of Credit notified previously in his favour, or for example to forward an advice of discrepancies to the applicant of an Import Letter of Credit.

More generally, the bank can use the generation of reporting from an existing record each time it needs to send a message to the customer and when this event is not a reply to something initiated by the client (in which case it would be accessed through the Pending Records module).
The flow to create these events is similar to the one described for the previous module.

New Transaction Status
Specify here the new status of the transaction record as it should be after the current event. This new status is the key information shown to the customer user when browsing the bank reporting or the history of the transaction.
Be careful to choose an appropriate code in view of the previous status - the system does not validate that the status is appropriate .
The dropdown list shows the possible values, which in the standard version of Fusion Corporate Channels are as follows (with sample interpretations):
Updated: a generic term to indicate that the record has been updated.
Amended : this status should be used only for acknowledgement or notification of Import or Export Commercial or Standby Letters of Credit and Banker's Guarantee amendments.
When the transaction status type selected is 'Amended' or 'Amendment Awaiting Beneficiary Approval' for Import Letter of Credit and Export Letter of Credit then FCC allows the user to use the code words in Narrative Details (refer Amendment section of Import Letter of Credit or Export Letter of Credit for details).
Amendment Awaiting Beneficiary Approval: this is used to notify the customer of the amendment being made to an LC which is awaiting beneficiary approval.
Extended: typically applicable to an extension of maturity date for a financing transaction.
Accepted: this could be used to notify the customer of an acceptance of bill.
Settled: to indicate any kind of principle settlement on any kind of product (for instance the full final settlement of Trust Receipt).
Partially Settled: same as above but reserved for partial settlements.
Cancelled: typically for the redemption and cancellation of a Shipping Guarantee.
Released: this status should typically be associated with a Banker's Guarantee whose release has been pronounced.
Discrepant: this status can be chosen by the bank on an Import LC when it notifies discrepancies detected on a set of documents presented.
Clean: the status can be chosen to mark an Import LC clean, which doesn't require any supporting documents.
Pre Advise of Bill Arrival: the status can be chosen to send an advance notification to customers of the Bill Arrival.
Partial Sight Payment: the status selected to make a partial payment on presentation of documents. Typically, this is chosen when the goods are being shipped in batches (partial shipment) and the payment follows the goods received.
Sight Payment: typically selected by the issuing bank of a Commercial or Standby LC when there is a presentation of documents with an underlying full sight payment, and if the presentation is clean or alternatively when the applicant has given his acceptance on discrepancies previously notified.
Amendment Awaiting Beneficiary Approval: the status to select to seek an approval from the beneficiary to amend an Import LC.
Cancel Awaiting Beneficiary Response: the status to select to seek an approval from the beneficiary to cancel an Import LC.
Cancel Refused: the status to refuse the cancel request from the beneficiary for an Import LC.
Purged: this is a technical code which will have a real impact on the file since the user will not be able to further update this record. It should be applied by the bank when it has purged the transaction in its own back-office system.
Expired: the status to mark an Import LC as expired.
Not Processed: this status should be used to mark a transaction as not processed.
Claim Presentation: this is a technical code that is used by the Middle Office user for presentation of claim under an existing Import LC, Banker's Guarantee or Issued Standby LC.
Warranty Claim: this is a technical code that is used by the Middle Office user for presentation of Claim under an existing Guarantee or Standby LC.
Claim Settlement: this is a technical code that is used by the Middle Office user to report the Claim Settlement under a Guarantee or Standby LC.
Extend/Pay: this is a technical code that is used by the Middle Office user to report the Extend/Pay request received from the Beneficiary of the Guarantee to the Fusion Corporate Channels Customer.
Notification of Charges: this is a status used by the Middle Office user to inform the customer about charges levied on a transaction and request action on it.
Request for Settlement: this is a status used by the Middle Office user to request the customer's approval for settlement of a transaction.
Wording Under Review: this status indicates that the provisional BG or provisional Issued SLC wording is under review by the customer and there could be a cycle of communication of negotiations before the deal is processed further.
Final Wording: this status indicates that the provisional BG or provisional Issued SLC wording has been accepted by the customer in the 'Wording Under Review' status and is now moved to this status for further processing.
'Wording Under Review' and 'Final Wording' options are available only for provisional BG or provisional Issued SLC. Customers should review the terms and move forward the transaction to the Bank by either accepting the wording or rejecting it.

Not Eligible: this status can be chosen by the bank to mark an invoice payable registered for APF - Buyer Uploads or APF - Seller Uploads by the customer, to be not eligible for financing.

Select the date of creation for the claim presentation. This value has to be the current date or earlier.

Expired: Mark an 'UI' or 'UA' transaction as expired.

Accepted: Used to notify the customer of an acceptance.
Cancelled: Typically for the redemption and cancellation of an Undertaking Issued or Undertaking Advised transaction.
Released: Associated with Undertaking Issued whose release has been pronounced.

When you select this option, you are presented with a list of messages that have been prepared and saved by users in your bank from existing records, but have not been successfully submitted to the clients because the user had insufficient privileges. section.title: Issued Standby Letter of Credit Form
section.para: Even though it is based on a flow of documents related to a business transaction between a buyer and seller, the Standby Letter of Credit is not directly related to the movement of goods.

It acts more like a guarantee. It means the beneficiary will receive a payment from the Issuing Bank in the event of default on a contract, provided that the complying documents (usually a sight draft) are presented.
A Standby Letter of Credit can be governed by either the UCP 500 rules or the more specific ISP 98 practices.

For business transactions that require regular exchanges between a buyer and a seller, a Standby Letter of Credit can include an Evergreen clause. This means the guarantee is automatically regularly renewed and so does not have an expiry date.

The Issued Standby LC focuses on the applicant side and is therefore very similar to the Import Letter of Credit seen previously. The key difference is that it can also be issued through a fairly unstructured form providing a large text area for the client to enter the details of the requested Standby LC.

When the bank edits a reporting message on this product, the form automatically inherits from the one used for its original issuance: if the Standby LC was initiated through a standard form, the same form as for an Import LC is displayed; if it was issued as a set of free format terms, the related form is loaded.
The following focuses on that free format option. For further details on the structured form, see the Import Letter of Credit section.

section.title: Shipping Guarantee Form
section.para: A Shipping Guarantee (SG) is an undertaking by a bank to the shipping owner or agent of a vessel, to release goods to the importer pending receipt of the original Bill of Lading. This helps the importer to clear the purchased goods under a Letter of Credit or a simple documentary collection while waiting for shipping documents to be presented. Hence it can for instance save the client from storage charges levied by the port authorities due to late arrival of the shipping documents or delays in clearance of the goods. Some Letters of Indemnity could also be handled through this module.

The form described below handles the business details of the SG product for which your bank is the guarantee Issuing Bank. It can be activated through the Edit Transaction Details feature found in the reporting page of the Pending and Existing Records when the product record edited is such a Shipping Guarantee.

section.para: A Financing Request or Trade Financing (TF) is a transaction issued in the Fusion Corporate Channels by the client and sent to a designated bank (the lender, also called Issuing Bank of the loan in the rest of this document) whereby that import or export customer requests some form of financing in the scope of an International Trade transaction.

The use of the Financing Requests module is quite generic in the sense that it aims at providing transaction handling capabilities for various types of financing such as Import Loans, Export Discounts on a presentation of documents by an exporter, as well as Trust Receipts or for instance Export Pre-Financing.

The form described in this section is dealing with the business details of a Financing Request for which your bank is the lending bank (also called TF Issuing Bank in the remainder of this document). It can be activated through the Edit Transaction Details feature found in the reporting page of the Pending and Existing Records when the product record edited is such a request for financing.

section.title: Export Documentary Collection Form
section.para: Documentary Collection is a method of payment used in international trade, whereby the exporter entrusts the handling of trade documents to banks and gives the banks instructions concerning the release of these documents to the importer.

Export Documentary Collection (often abbreviated to Export Collection) refers to the export side of such transactions where the bank plays the role of the Remitting Bank and where the client is the drawer of the collection.
Two types of Export Collections are handled:

listitem.para: Regular Collections where the remitting bank will be responsible for the sending of the documents to the presenting bank on the import side,
Direct Collections where the drawer himself ships the documents to the presenting bank and only instruct his bank to handle the remaining of the transaction.

section.title: Generating the Cover Letter
section.para: During the initial receipt of the Direct Collection instructions by the Remitting Bank, you can optionally use Fusion Corporate Channels to generate and submit to your customer the actual cover letter that the customer will use to send directly the documents to the Presenting Bank. This method circumvents a classical flaw of direct collections whereby the Remitting Bank is reluctant to provide its customer with blank forms bearing its letterhead without any control on them.
The built-in flow for the generation and attachment of the cover letter is the following:

listitem.para: The bank receives the request through the middle-office screen and prepares the reporting bearing its approval of the collection instructions.

While performing this task on a direct collection record, you can decide to automatically generate and attach the related cover letter. This is done in Input mode by checking a dedicated check box in the Reporting Message Details section of the screen. At any time, with the icon
, you can call a preview of the letter available as an Acrobat PDF file.

When you click Save / Submit, the server-side logic generates a new attachment and adds it to the list of files attached to the reporting message. This PDF file becomes the original copy that the customer will receive, and subsequently print and attach to the documents sent to the import side.

section.para: Undertaking is an independent, documentary undertaking by which the bank issues, at the request of its customer (the instructing party / applicant) its irrevocable guarantee to pay a sum of money to a third party, (the beneficiary), provided a complying demand is made.

It is usually a “passive instrument” in the sense that, once issued, it is not expected to be drawn on, because the applicant/instructing party and beneficiary will generally settle the underlying contract/relationship outside of the undertaking. The undertaking remains until its expiry and serves as security under the commercial transaction. In most cases, demands are only made when the applicant/instructing party is in breach of its underlying contract/relationship.
A payment is made to the beneficiary against a demand and presentation of specified documentation and in accordance with the terms of the undertaking.
The form described below reflects this role and presents the business data available to the bank user to follow-up with the Undertaking Issued record initiated by its clients.

section.title: Fund Transfer Product
section.para: In an international trade transaction, a client can use this Funds Transfer (FT) module to request a fund transfer, for which the bank (called the Ordering Bank) can subsequently send an acknowledgement upon successful completion.

The Funds Transfer module is a simple Cash Management feature. It enables an applicant company to do two types of transfer: Internal, which the client uses to transfer funds between two accounts both belonging to the client, and Outgoing, which the client uses when an external beneficiary is the recipient of the transfer, possibly with another banking institution acting as an intermediary. An outgoing transfer is also called a third-party transfer.

Unlike the other products in Fusion Corporate Channels, the Funds Transfer module is associated with a single event (the submission of the transfer request and the bank's reply), and therefore has no free format message feature for further interaction between client and bank.

Therefore the bank side of the Fund Transfer product is limited to a review of the instructions sent by the client and the interaction is limited to the common input fields available for every reporting message generated by the bank from a pending customer request. See the chapter detailing this common function for further details.

chapter.title: Collaboration Suite Module
chapter.para: The Collaboration Suite enhances the level of communication between the different actors of international cash and trade operations.

note.para: Collaboration Suite is available for the customers' users, and on middle-office, for both cash and trade. For Counterparties, it is available only for trade.

section.title: Overview
section.para: A user at a client company can:

listitem.para: Create a list of tasks for any event of any cash and trade product (Import Letter of Credit, Banker's Guarantee, Funds Transfer, Remittance and so on).
Assign tasks to users in their company, and follow up each these tasks through reports and a system of automatic alerts.
Assign tasks to your bank and communicate freely with the bank during the preparation phase of a transaction.
Assign tasks to a counterparty and communicate freely with the counterparty during the preparation phase of a transaction.

section.para: Typically, a task is a question asked by a client user, who needs information from a colleague, a counterparty or the bank in order to complete the transaction.

A user at a client company can assign one or more tasks related to a transaction to your bank. As a user at the bank, you will see it in one of several lists displayed in your Fusion Corporate Channels interface. You can reply by adding a comment to it, or mark it completed. Your comments are visible to all users at the client company (who have access to the transaction) via the Fusion Corporate Channels interface. The bank users can add comments to a task until the client submits the transaction; after that, it can only be viewed in read-only mode.
You can also use this system to maintain a private list of tasks for yourself to do.

section.title: Task Windows
section.para: Your bank user interface has three different windows that display lists of tasks. We describe here the different ways they are used. Later sections in this chapter describe their layout in detail.

section.title: Collaboration Window (Tasks)
section.para: When you view a product initiation request, the form that opens has attached to it a free-floating window entitled Tasks. This is known as the Collaboration Window. It is initially displayed minimized when the form opens. Click the maximize button on its title bar to see it fully.

You use this window to view and reply to tasks for the transaction you are processing. To reply to a task, you add a comment to it. To do this, click Comments by its entry to display all its existing comments, and then click Post Comment. These comments typically form a conversation between the client user who created a task and the bank user who carries it out.
The client user who created a task can also edit it, so you might find its original text updated at times during this conversation.

Each task has a check box on the left-hand side. This is called the completion check box. The user who carries out the task should click to put a check mark here. Once this is done, the creator can no longer edit the task, but people can still add comments to it.
The Collaboration Window has a second part headed My Tasks. Here you can create a private list, visible only to you, of tasks you intend to do yourself.

section.title: Ongoing Tasks
section.para: This list is part of your home page. It lists all tasks that are available for you to do. That is, tasks you've created for yourself to do, and tasks that client users have assigned to your bank so that any user at your bank can pick the task and do it.
One column shows the System Id of the transaction that the task is attached to. Clicking this opens the form, including the Collaboration Window, for further editing of the transaction.
When another user updates a task, the change appears on your Ongoing Tasks list as soon as you refresh your screen (typically done using F5).
The Ongoing Tasks list does not show comments. Once a task has been marked completed, it disappears from this list.

section.title: Tasks Monitoring
section.para: You access this list by clicking MIddle-Office on your main menu to display the Administration menu, and then clicking Tasks Monitoring. This is the fullest list, in that it can show all tasks, both open and completed, and all comments. It has search criteria fields, so you can select which items to show.

note.para: The Date range fields both default to today's date, so when you first display the list you see only the entries created today.

section.title: Associating Counterparty(ies) With Customers
section.para: Administrators at your bank maintain a list of companies that your bank deals with. For example, when creating an Export LC notification, you fill in the beneficiary field by selecting a company from this list. These companies are called counterparties.

Similarly, administrators at a client company can create and maintain a list of counterparties that their company deals with. A client administrator who has the Collaboration Suite enabled can, in defining a new counterparty, create a login ID for that counterparty. This enables users at the counterparty to connect to Fusion Corporate Channels to see tasks assigned to their company.

Furthermore, an administrator at your bank who has the Collaboration Suite enabled can associate counterparties created by one client with other clients as well. This enables these other clients to deal with the counterparty too. Moreover, any initiation of a trade product is immediately notified to the counterparty. For example, when an initiation of Import Letter of Credit is validated by the Issuing Bank, it is immediately advised to the beneficiary as an Export Letter of Credit.

note.para: Collaboration for counterparties is a trade-specific feature.
